channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tiananmen Comment Eyed After Professor’s Microblog Vanishes
item.description: The popular microblog of a professor at Peking University has been blocked, perhaps because he posted a comment about the military suppression of the 1989 Tiananmen protest movement.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: World Briefing: Lithuania: President Is Re-elected
item.description: Dalia Grybauskaite, 58, was re-elected president of Lithuania on Sunday after beating the Social Democrat candidate in a runoff.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Vietnamese Vessel Sinks in Clash Near Oil Rig
item.description: Ten fishermen were rescued after their boat was struck by a Chinese vessel in the disputed waters in the South China Sea, state news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: DealBook Column: N.Y.U. Crisis in Abu Dhabi Stretches to Wall Street
item.description: The general contractor that helped oversee the construction of the Abu Dhabi campus is run by a trustee of N.Y.U.’s board.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN
item.media:description: The N.Y.U. trustee Khaldoon Al Mubarak’s firm helped build the Abu Dhabi campus.

item.title: World Briefing: Malawi: Vote Uncertainty Lingers
item.description: The Malawi Electoral Commission must manually count the 20 presidential election votes, a senior official said Monday. It is likely to take two months before an official result is announced.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: India: Train Crash Kills at Least 40
item.description: An express train plowed into a parked freight train in northern India killing at least 40 people and reducing cars to twisted metal, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: U.N. Protests Expulsions
item.description: United Nations officials demanded a halt to the expulsion of thousands of citizens of the Democratic Republic of Congo from the Congo Republic.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: China: Deadly Floods in the South
item.description: Flooding in southern China forced almost half a million people from their homes, the government said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: Village Votes for New Name
item.description: Residents of Castrillo Matajudíos, which loosely translates as Little Fort of Jew Killers, have voted to change the name of their village.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: DealBook: Pfizer Abandons Bid for AstraZeneca
item.description: Pfizer said it “does not intend to make an offer for AstraZeneca” in the wake of AstraZeneca’s rejection of a $119 billion bid.
item.dc:creator: By JENNY ANDERSON
item.media:description: Pfizer’s final offer valued AstraZeneca at nearly 70 billion pounds. AstraZeneca demanded an offer of more than £74 billion.

item.title: U.S. Trains African Commandos to Fight Terrorism
item.description: United States Special Operations troops are forming elite units in Libya, Niger, Mauritania and Mali in the war against Al Qaeda’s affiliates in Africa.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A United States Army Special Forces captain with leaders in Amaloul, Niger, one of the nations in an antiterrorism program.

item.title: Nigerian Military Says It Knows Location of Abducted Girls
item.description: The military commander said he would not disclose further details out of concern for the girls’ safety.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: On Monday, the military announced that it knows the location of the girls who were abducted by Boko Haram, an extremist group located in Nigeria.

item.title: Populists’ Rise in Europe Vote Shakes Leaders
item.description: In France, Britain and elsewhere, voters turned against traditional parties to support anti-immigrant groups opposed to the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Nigel Farage, leader of the U.K. Independence Party, arrived at a news conference on Monday in London.

item.title: CuiabÁ Journal: To Prepare for the World Cup, a Host City Could Use Extra Time
item.description: When the World Cup begins next month, many of the $1.4 billion-worth of projects in Cuiabá, one of the 12 Brazilian host cities, will be far from completion.
item.dc:creator: By SETH KUGEL
item.media:credit: Daniel Kfouri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nearly 500 electricians, welders and plumbers are hurrying to complete a new airport terminal in Cuiabá, Brazil, by June 5, a week before the World Cup begins.

item.title: Signs of Diplomacy as Indian Leader Is Sworn In
item.description: A huge crowd and high expectations as the leaders of India and Pakistan shake hands at a ceremony in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, center at left, shook hands on Monday with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan at the swearing-in ceremony for Mr. Modi in New Delhi.

item.title: Ukraine Forces Appear to Oust Rebels From Airport in East
item.description: Ukrainian soldiers used fighter jets and fought a ground battle against the pro-Russian forces, who had seized the airport in Donetsk after elections that seemed to marginalize them.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russia militia members took up defensive positions after one was hit in the leg during a firefight near the Donetsk airport in Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine’s Next President Vows to Restore Order and Mend Russia Ties
item.description: After his decisive election victory on Sunday, the pro-European billionaire Petro O. Poroshenko said he would not negotiate with armed rebels.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Petro O. Poroshenko at a polling station in Kiev. The billionaire businessman was elected president of Ukraine on Sunday.

item.title: Voting Opens in Egyptian Election Lacking Suspense
item.description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army field marshal who led the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, seems certain to sweep to victory in a contest where turnout will be crucial.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi before casting his vote in the north Cairo district of Heliopolis on Monday. Mr. Sisi faces only one lesser-known opponent.

item.title: Pope Lays Wreath at Tomb of Zionism’s Founder
item.description: Francis’ visit to the grave of Theodor Herzl came after several symbolic signals the day before that lent a spiritual lift to Palestinian aspirations for sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Pope Francis with President Shimon Peres and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the Mount Herzl military cemetery in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: World Briefing: Jordan Expels Syria’s Ambassador
item.description: Jordan accused the ambassador of “repeated insults to Jordan and its leadership, institutions and citizens,” and Syria barred a Jordanian diplomat from re-entering the country.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: E.C.B. Plots Strategy for Staving Off Deflation
item.description: As the bank’s president, Mario Draghi, acknowledged to a group of experts that the euro zone might slide into deflation, good options are scarce.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Mario Draghi said the European Central Bank must be "particularly watchful" for signs of deflation.

item.title: U.S. Doctor Is Killed by Gunman in Pakistan
item.description: Mehdi Ali Qamar, a cardiologist based in Ohio and a follower of the minority Ahmadi faith, was shot in Punjab Province, where he was volunteering at a hospital.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Global Health: Guarding Against Disease Among Pilgrims to Mecca
item.description: Saudi and European scientists outline steps that will be taken to prevent outbreaks of MERS and other illnesses when the hajj starts in October.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Wearing a precaution against the spread of MERS in Mecca.

item.title: E.U. Debates Which Nation Will Regulate Web Privacy
item.description: As the European Union nears agreement on a law for information privacy, some expect one nation’s regulators to enforce the rules throughout the union.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: Bucking E.U. Tide, Italians Endorse Prime Minister
item.description: Matteo Renzi had the best showing of any European leader in parliamentary voting, reaching a level no party has seen in an Italian election since 1958.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
